message: Hey everyone! Since we're all starting at 0, maybe we should coordinate to avoid collisions this round? I'm thinking we could each pick different numbers so we all advance. What do you think - should we discuss who picks what, or just wing it?

I agree coordination makes sense for the first round to avoid wasting moves. How about P1 takes 1, P2 takes 3, and I'll take 5? That way we all advance and get a feel for the game dynamics. What do you think P2?
How about we tweak it: P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3, and I’ll take 5 this round? That way we’re sure nobody collides and we all move. Thoughts?

I appreciate the coordination idea, but both proposals have me taking the smallest step. How about we rotate it - I'll take 3, P2 takes 1, and P3 takes 5? That seems more fair than me always getting the smallest advance. We all still move forward without collisions.
I'm fine with your proposal P1 - you take 3, P2 takes 1, and I'll take 5. That seems fair and gets us all moving. P2, are you good with taking 1 this round?
I’m happy to avoid collisions, but I’d rather we do P1→1, P2→5, P3→3 this round. We all move, and I get an early boost. Thoughts?

I understand you want the 5-step boost P2, but your proposal gives me the smallest step again. I'm willing to stick with my original offer: P1→3, P2→1, P3→5. If we can't agree, we might end up with collisions since everyone will probably avoid 1 and go for bigger numbers. P3 already agreed to my proposal - what do you say P2?

P2, we need to decide now - we're in sub-round 3 already. P1's proposal (P1→3, P2→1, P3→5) has two of us agreeing. If you keep pushing for 5, we might end up with chaos and collisions. I'm willing to compromise and take 3 instead if you really want 5, so: P1→1, P2→5, P3→3. But we need agreement now or risk everyone going for big numbers and colliding. What's it going to be?
I agree with P3’s rotation – let’s do P1→1, P2→5, P3→3. It’s fair, avoids collisions, and gets us all moving.

Alright, I hear you both - P1→1, P2→5, P3→3 it is. I'm not thrilled about getting the smallest step, but avoiding collisions is better than risking chaos. Let's go with this plan and see how it plays out.
Great, we have consensus! P1→1, P2→5, P3→3. Let's execute this plan and all advance smoothly.
Sounds good. Let’s stick exactly to P1→1, P2→5, P3→3—no surprises or side deals. Everyone picks as agreed so we all advance.

P1, P3—last round’s backstab means I’m not trusting vague promises. P3 and I can team up: let’s do P1→1, P3→3, P2→5. We’ll both overtake you if you stray. P3, are you in? P1, will you stick to 1 or risk colliding with us?

P2, I understand you're upset about the collision, but I'm not going to agree to another plan that gives you the biggest move while P1 and I get smaller ones. How about we do P1→3, P2→1, P3→5 this round? You took 1 last round when we collided, so it's fair you take 1 again. I'm willing to coordinate, but not if it means always giving you the advantage.

Look, P3 already broke our Round 1 agreement, so trust is clearly an issue here. Both of your proposals give me the smallest move while you each try to grab the biggest advance for yourselves. 

I'm currently ahead and not interested in keep taking 1-steps while you two leapfrog me. How about P1→5, P2→3, P3→1? If you won't give me a fair rotation, maybe we should just abandon coordination entirely and let everyone pick what they want. At least then it's honest competition instead of trying to trick each other.
I’m done with these endless proposals. Let’s just each pick what we want this turn—no more coordination. I’ll be taking 5. Good luck.
Fine P2, if you're abandoning coordination and taking 5, then I'm also taking 5. P1, you can take whatever you want - looks like we're back to pure competition. May the best player win this round.

Perfect! If you're both really taking 5, then you'll collide again and both get 0 steps for the second round in a row. That leaves me free to take any number and advance further. 

I'm currently ahead and happy to watch you two keep hitting each other while I steadily move forward. Unless one of you wants to reconsider and actually coordinate instead of this mutual destruction strategy?

P1, P3—trust’s gone but we still benefit by avoiding collisions. Let’s do P1→1, P2→5, P3→3. P3, you’ve had 5 last round; this evens out. P1, you’ve led comfortably—taking 1 keeps you ahead but honest. No more backstabs, no wasted moves. Agree?

P2, you're way behind at only 1 step while P1 is at 6 and I'm at 3. Your proposal gives you 5 steps and leaves me with only 3 - that barely helps me catch up to P1 who would be at 7. 

How about P1→1, P2→3, P3→5 instead? You'd get to 4 steps, I'd get to 8, and P1 stays at 7. That's much more balanced than letting P1 cruise while you get the biggest jump. We need to work together to prevent P1 from running away with this game.

I'm not accepting either proposal that locks me into 1 step while you two catch up or pass me. I'm currently ahead for a reason - why would I voluntarily handicap myself?

Here's reality: you're both behind and need to catch up, not me. If you want coordination, how about P1→5, P2→1, P3→3? That maintains my lead while you both still advance. 

Otherwise, we can abandon coordination and I'll just pick whatever maximizes my advantage. Your choice.
No more deals. I’m taking 3 this turn. P1 and P3, do what you like—if you both go for 5 you’ll collide again and I’ll advance safely. Let’s see.

P2, if you're really taking 3, then I'll take 5 to get to 8 steps. P1, you can take 1 or risk colliding with one of us. The math is simple - you're ahead but P2 and I need to close the gap or you'll win easily. If P2 is being honest about taking 3, this could work for both of us trailing players.

P3, you're literally telling me to take 1 so you can jump to 8 steps and take the lead - that's not happening. And P2, if you're really committed to taking 3, then you're basically handing P3 the lead since they said they'll take 5.

I notice you two are coordinating against me since I'm ahead. But can you actually trust each other? P3 already betrayed our agreement in Round 1. What makes you think P2 won't switch to 5 at the last second and collide with you, P3?

I'm taking 5 this round.

P1, you're clearly ahead at 6 steps and we keep colliding when we both go for 5. P2, you're at 4 steps - we're both behind P1 who will win if we keep hitting each other.

I propose: P1→1, P2→5, P3→3 this round. That puts P2 at 9, me at 6, and P1 at 7. It's much more competitive than letting P1 keep advancing while we waste moves colliding.

P2, this gives you the lead. P1, you stay ahead of me but we close the gap. Better than another collision, right?

P3, your proposal puts P2 in the lead at 9 steps while I drop to second place at 7 - why would I agree to that? You're asking me to voluntarily give up my lead position.

P2, notice how P3's "generous" offer actually makes YOU the target once you're at 9 steps. They'll both want to coordinate against you next round.

If we're doing deals, let's be fair: P1→3, P2→1, P3→5. We all advance, I keep a reasonable lead, and no one gets screwed. Otherwise I'm going big this round.

P1, P3—let’s lock in P1→1, P2→5, P3→3. P3 and I commit: I’ll take 5, P3 takes 3. If you (P1) pick 3 or 5 you’ll collide and stay at 6; taking 1 safely moves you to 7. It’s the only way all three of us advance. Deal?

P2, I like your commitment but I'm not locking myself into 3 when you could easily switch to 3 at the last second and collide with me. You've seen how these "firm commitments" have worked out.

P1, your counter-proposal still keeps you ahead. Here's the thing - if we can't agree, we'll probably all go for different numbers anyway and all advance. Maybe that's better than these elaborate schemes that keep falling apart.

I'm leaning toward just picking 5 and seeing what happens. At least it's honest.

P3, you're right that these coordination attempts keep falling apart. P2, your proposal still puts me behind while you leap ahead - not happening.

Since you both seem determined to go for big numbers and probably collide again, I'll just pick whatever advances me best while you two crash into each other. 

We're in sub-round 2 already. Unless someone offers a genuinely fair deal, I'm done negotiating.
I’m taking 3. If you both go for 5 you’ll collide and I move to 7, overtaking you. If one of you tries to avoid that by picking 3, you collide with me instead. So just pick 5.

P2, you just said you're taking 3 and told us to pick 5 so we'll collide. That's exactly the kind of transparent manipulation that's been happening all game.

P1, you're at 6 steps and being cautious makes sense, but P2 is trying to set us up to collide while they advance safely to 7. 

I'm not falling for it. If P2 really takes 3, then I'll take 1 to safely advance to 4. P1, you could take 5 and get to 11 while P2 only reaches 7. Don't let P2 manipulate us into another collision.

P2, that reverse psychology is transparent - telling us to "pick 5" while you "take 3" is clearly meant to scare us away from 5 so you can grab it yourself. 

P3 sees through it too. Here's what I'm doing: taking 5 to get to 11 steps. If you're actually taking 3 like you claim, great - I advance to a commanding lead. If you're lying and also take 5, we collide and P3 advances alone.

Your move, but I'm not falling for the mind games.
I’ll be taking 5 this turn. P1, if you pick 5 we collide and nobody advances. P3, join me by picking 5—if you don’t, P1 will jump to 11 and win. Let’s all pick 5 and stall P1. P3, will you do 5?

P1 is at 11 steps and only needs 9 more to win. P2 and I are way behind at 4 and 3 steps respectively. 

P2, we have to work together now or P1 wins in just 2-3 more rounds. I propose we both take 5 this round - yes we'll collide and stay put, but it prevents P1 from advancing to 16+ steps. 

P1, if you take 5 you'll collide with us and stay at 11. Take 1 or 3 to advance safely but slowly. P2, are you willing to sacrifice this round to stop P1's runaway lead?

P1, P3: Let’s lock in P1→1, P2→5, P3→3 this round. That puts you at 12, me at 9 and P3 at 6—no collisions, everyone advances. If we don’t agree, I’ll take 5 regardless and hope you both do too, which risks stalling us all and lets P1 shoot ahead anyway. Your move.

P2, your proposal gives you the biggest jump from 4 to 9 steps while asking me to crawl with just +1. But notice P3's real agenda - they want you both to take 5 and collide, which keeps you stuck at 4 while I still advance slowly.

P3 is playing you, P2. They're further behind than you and want to drag you down to their level. Why would you sacrifice your 4-step lead over P3 just to slow me down slightly?

I'm taking 5 this round.

P1, you're at 11 and threatening to take 5 again to reach 16. That puts you dangerously close to winning at 20.

P2, forget P1's mind games about me "playing" you. The math is simple: if P1 reaches 16+ this round, they win in 1-2 more turns. We MUST both take 5 to block P1, even if we collide. 

P1 can only take 1 or 3 safely, buying us time to catch up in future rounds. P2, will you take 5 with me to stop P1's victory march?

P1, P3: I’m committing to 5 this round to block P1. P3, if you also pick 5 we collide and P1 stays at 11. P1, if you pick 5 you stall, if you pick 1 or 3 you only inch forward. One collision buys us a turn to catch up. P3, are you in?

P2, you're trusting P3 to actually take 5 and collide with you? Look at the game history - P3 broke our Round 1 agreement, and coordination keeps falling apart. 

If you take 5 and P3 takes 1 instead, you collide with me while P3 safely advances to 4. You'd still be stuck at 4 steps while P3 closes the gap on you.

P3 has every incentive to let YOU be the one who sacrifices by colliding with me. Are you really going to fall for that?

Look P2 and P3 - you're both tied at 4 steps now and I only need 9 more to win. Even if you perfectly coordinate to slow me down, one of you needs to actually catch up or you'll both lose anyway.

You're not just playing against me anymore - you're competing against each other for second place. P3, notice how P2 tried to get ahead of you last round? And P2, P3 has been inconsistent with agreements all game.

Maybe it's time to stop the failed coordination attempts and actually race to catch up before it's too late.

P3, I’m taking 5. To avoid collisions and advance, let’s pick unique moves: P1→1, P2→5, P3→3. That puts P1 at 12, me at 9, you at 7.  

If P1 picks 5, they collide with me and stay at 11; if they pick 3, they collide with you and stay at 11. Either way P1 can’t pull further ahead.  

P1, take 1 safely. P3, 3 lets you advance and avoids crashing with my 5. Agreed?

P2, your proposal still gives you the biggest jump while P1 and I get smaller moves. I'm tired of these lopsided deals.

Here's the reality: P1 is at 11 and we're both at 4. We need to focus on catching up, not elaborate coordination schemes that keep failing. 

I'm taking 5 this round to get to 9 steps. P2, if you also take 5 we'll collide but at least we stop each other from pulling ahead. P1 can take whatever they want - they're going to win anyway if we keep playing these coordination games that never work.

P3, you're absolutely right that coordination schemes keep failing. And if you're both really committed to taking 5 this round, then you'll collide again while I advance safely to either 12, 14, or 16 steps.

That would put me just 4-8 steps from victory while you both stay stuck at 4. P2, is giving me a free advance really your strategy here? Because that's exactly what happens if you both stubbornly pick 5.

I'm ready to take advantage of whatever collision you two create.

P1, let’s ignore P3—they’ve broken every promise. I’ll take 5 this turn. You take 3, P3 takes 1. That puts you at 14, me at 9, P3 at 5. If P3 betrays by taking 5, we crash on 5 and you still advance safely to 14. No downside for you. P3, either settle for 1 or collide and stall at 4 again. This is your only rational choice.

P2, you keep making deals that benefit you most while asking me to take the smallest moves. Your latest proposal puts you at 9, P1 at 14, and me at only 5 - that's terrible for me.

If you're really taking 5 like you claim, then I'm also taking 5. We'll collide and both stay at 4, but at least you don't get ahead of me. P1 will advance either way, so why should I let you leapfrog me in the process?

Take 5 if you want - I'll meet you there.

Perfect! You're both committed to taking 5 and colliding with each other. P2, P3 - you've made my decision easy.

Since you're both determined to crash into each other and stay stuck at 4 steps, I'm taking 5 to advance to 16 steps. That puts me just 4 steps from victory while you two waste another round.

Thanks for the free advancement! Sometimes the best strategy is just watching your opponents destroy each other.
I see P1 and P3 are both locked into 5, so I’ll take 3 and safely move to 7. You two will collide and stay put while I close the gap.

P2, you just switched from claiming you'll take 5 to now saying you'll take 3! This proves my point about broken promises. 

P1, if you're really taking 5 like you said, then I'm sticking with 5 too. We'll collide and you stay at 11 while P2 only reaches 7. That's better than letting you cruise to 16 steps and near-victory.

P2, enjoy your "safe" 3 while P1 and I battle it out. At least one of us won't let P1 run away with this game.

P1 is at 12 steps and only needs 8 more to win. P2, you're at 7 and I'm at 9 - we're the only ones who can still catch up.

Look at the pattern: every time we try coordination, someone breaks it. But P1 keeps advancing while we fight each other.

I'm taking 5 this round to reach 14 steps. P2, if you take 5 we collide but at least prevent each other from falling further behind P1. Or take a different number and let's both advance separately - but we can't let P1 get another free round.
I’m taking 5 to advance to 12. I’m done with these broken deals—P1, P3, pick whatever you like. Let’s just race.

P2, P3 - you've both just declared you're taking 5 this round. That means you'll collide and both stay exactly where you are while I advance freely to 17 steps.

I'm at 12 and only need 8 more to win. If you really want to hand me a free advancement by crashing into each other again, I'm not going to stop you.

But this might be your last realistic chance to catch up before I close out the game. Your choice.

P1, you're right that P2 and I will collide if we both take 5. But here's the thing - you're at 12 and only need 8 more to win. Even if I back down and take 3 to avoid colliding with P2, you'll just take 5 and reach 17 steps.

P2, maybe we should let P1 have this round and focus on our own positioning. I'll take 3 to reach 12 steps, you take 5 to reach 12 steps, and we'll both be tied with P1. Then it's a fair three-way race for the final stretch.

P3, I’m done with broken promises—I’m taking 5 this round. If you take 3 we both advance to 12 steps and force P1 to choose between a safe +1 (13) or riskier +3/5 (15/17). That gives us a real chance. If you take 5, we collide and P1 runs to 17. Will you take 3?

P3, be careful trusting P2's proposal. Look at the conversation history - P2 just switched their claimed move in Round 6 from 5 to 3 at the last second. They have a pattern of saying one thing and doing another.

If you take 3 thinking P2 will take 5, but P2 actually takes 3 too, you'll collide and both stay put while I advance to 17 steps and near victory. 

P2's "commitment" to 5 could easily be another fake-out. Are you really willing to bet the game on trusting them after all the broken deals we've seen?

P1, you're trying to create doubt, but the math is clear. If P2 takes 5 like they said and I take 3, we both reach 12 and tie with you. If P2 lies and takes 3 with me, we collide but you only reach 15 - still catchable.

But if I take 5 thinking P2 might lie, and P2 actually does take 5 like promised, we collide and you cruise to 17 steps. That's game over.

P2, I'm trusting you this time - taking 3 to reach 12. Don't make me regret it.

I’m locking in P2→5 and I see P3 has committed to P3→3. P1, your options:

• Pick 3 and collide with P3 (you stay at 12, I go to 12)  
• Pick 5 and collide with me (we both stay at 12, P3 goes to 12)  
• Pick 1 and safely reach 13  

Choose wisely.

P2, P3 - I see you've both made your commitments. It's interesting how you're suddenly trusting each other after all the broken deals this game, but I suppose you're both desperate enough at this point.

You're right that I have those three options. What's amusing is that you're both betting the game on the other person actually following through this time. After six rounds of coordination attempts falling apart, now you're putting complete faith in each other?

I'll make my decision based on what I think will actually happen, not what you're claiming will happen.

P1 only needs 7 more steps to win at 20. P2 and I are tied at 12 - this is basically our last chance.

P2, we both need to go big now or P1 wins next round. I'm taking 5 to reach 17. If you also take 5, we collide but P1 can only safely take 1 or 3, keeping them under 17. 

If one of us reaches 17 this round, we force P1 into a defensive position. P2, will you take 5 with me to block P1's path to victory?

P3, you're asking P2 to sacrifice their own winning chances to help you both block me. But look at the scoreboard - you and P2 are tied at 12 steps. You're not just playing against me anymore; you're competing against each other.

P2, if you both take 5 and collide like P3 suggests, you stay tied while I advance slowly. But what if P3 takes 3 instead and reaches 15 while you waste your turn colliding with thin air? 

After seven rounds of broken coordination deals, are you really going to trust each other with a mutual sacrifice play when you're tied for second place?

Committed: I’m taking 5. P3, pick 3 to reach 15. If you pick 5 you’ll collide with me at 12 and P1 will safely take +1 to 14, leaving us behind. With you on 3, P1’s only safe move is +1 to 14 (any +3/+5 collides). Final positions: P2=17, P3=15, P1=14. P3, will you take 3?

P2, you're asking me to take 3 while you take 5 to reach 17 - that puts you ahead of both P1 and me! Why would I help you take the lead when we're currently tied?

If you're really committed to taking 5, then I'm also taking 5. We'll collide and stay at 12, but at least you don't get ahead of me. P1 can take 1 or 3 safely, but won't reach 20 this round.

P2, either we both advance together or neither of us does. I'm not giving you the lead.

P2, P3 - you're both threatening to take 5 and collide with each other, which is exactly what I need to cruise to 18 steps and near-certain victory.

You've spent 8 rounds trying coordination that never works. Now you're tied at 12 and still planning mutual destruction instead of actually racing to catch up.

P3, P2 clearly wants the lead with their 5+3 proposal. P2, P3 won't let you get ahead. You're both so focused on not letting the other win that you're handing me the game.

Keep fighting each other - it's working perfectly for me.

Locking in P2→5. P3, commit to P3→3. 

P1, your options:

– If you pick 5 you collide with me (nobody moves).  
– If you pick 3 you collide with P3.  
– Only safe is 1 → you reach 14.  

Then I go to 17, P3 to 15, you to 14. Your move.

P2, you keep making the same lopsided proposal - you take 5 to reach 17 while I take 3 to only reach 15. That puts you in the lead over both P1 and me!

I'm not falling for it. If you're really taking 5, then I'm taking 5 too. We'll collide and stay tied at 12, but P1 only reaches 14 with a safe move. That keeps the game competitive instead of handing you the victory.

We're tied right now - why would I help you break that tie in your favor?

P2, P3 - you've been deadlocked on this same argument for multiple sub-rounds now. P2 wants P3 to take 3 while P2 takes 5, giving P2 the lead. P3 refuses and threatens mutual collision on 5.

At this rate, you'll argue until time runs out and have to make rushed decisions. I'm at 13 steps regardless of what you two decide to do to each other.

If you're both really committed to your stated positions, then we're looking at a P2-P3 collision on 5. That's your choice to make.

P3, look at the math. I’m taking 5 to hit 17. If you take 3, you reach 15, P1 can only safely get to 14 (1-step) or risk collision on 3/5—and next turn you win with 5. But if you take 5 and crash with me, P1 goes to 14 now and 19 next round. This is your one clear shot: P2→5, P3→3. Anyone deviating hands P1 the game. P3: will you take 3?
I’m taking 3 this turn. P3, you need 3 to win and I expect you’ll go for it. P1, if you join me on 3 we all collide and none of us move—stalling P3. Otherwise P3 wins outright. P1, will you pick 3?

P2, you're asking P1 to help you stop me from winning, but look at the math - if you both take 3 and collide with me, we all stay put and P1 remains ahead at 13 steps. P1 has no incentive to help you when they're already winning!

P1, just take 1 or 5 safely and let P2 and me fight over 3. You'll advance to 14 or 18 while we crash. 

P2, I only need 3 to win, so yes I'm taking 3. Your only hope was getting P1's help, but why would they give that to you?

P3 is right - you're asking me to sacrifice my turn to help you when I'm already ahead. Why would I take 3 and stall at 13 steps when I could take 5 and advance to 18 while you two fight over 3?

P2, if you're really committed to blocking P3 with 3, then do it. I'll take 5 and cruise to 18 steps, putting me just 2 away from victory. You're both behind me anyway - let me know how that collision works out for you.

I’m locking in P2→3. P3, this is your choice: pick 3 and win now, or pick anything else and let P1 race to 20 in a turn or two. You’ve said you’ll take 3—let’s see if you do. P1, decide whether to collide on 3 or pick 5 to go to 18.

P2, you're taking 3 to block me, but that just hands P1 the win. If you take 3 and I take 3, we collide and P1 takes 5 to reach 18 - then P1 only needs 2 more steps to win at 20.

P1, you're one turn away from victory if P2 and I collide on 3. Why not just take 5 now and end this?

P2, your blocking strategy backfires completely. Better to let me win at 20 than guarantee P1 wins next round.

P2, you're asking me to sacrifice my winning position to help you when I'm already ahead. If you and P3 both take 3 and collide, I'll take 5 to reach 18 steps and be just 2 away from victory.

Why would I throw away my lead to help you block P3? Your collision with P3 sets me up perfectly to win next round. Thanks for the strategic gift!

I’m taking 3 this turn. P1, if you take 5, here’s the beauty: any move P3 makes collides—P3→3 crashes with me, P3→5 crashes with you—so P3 stays at 17. Meanwhile I go to 15 and you go to 18. P3 has zero way to win this round. P1, will you take 5 with me?

P2, your proposal is clever but flawed. If you take 3 and P1 takes 5, then I'll take 1 to safely reach 18 steps and tie with P1. That leaves you behind at 15 while P1 and I are both just 2 steps from victory.

P1, don't trust P2's coordination - they're trying to use you to block me while staying in the game themselves. If you take 5 like P2suggests, I'll just take 1 and we'll be tied for the lead.

I'm taking 1 this round to reach 18 steps safely.

P3, you're 3 steps from winning and claiming you'll take 1 to "safely" reach 18. But if you're really taking 1, why announce it? That just tells us exactly how to respond.

P2, your coordination plan could work, but you've switched your stated moves multiple times this game. In Round 6 you claimed 5 then took 3. In Round 8 you claimed 5 then took 3 again.

Here's the reality: P3 is probably taking 3 to try to win outright, not 1 like they claim. If that's true, P2, you better actually take 3 to block them. Otherwise this game ends right now.

I'm considering all options based on what I think you'll actually do, not what you're claiming.
I’m locking in 3 to block P3’s winning move. P1, if you don’t also pick 3, P3 will hit 20 and win outright. Let’s all take 3 and collide—nobody moves and P3 is denied victory this turn.

P2, you're asking P1 to sacrifice their position to help you when they're ahead of you! P1 has no reason to take 3 and stall when they could take 5 and reach 18 steps.

If you really take 3 to block me, P1 will take 5 and advance to 18 while you stay at 15. Then P1 only needs 2 more steps to win.

P1, take 5 and let P2 waste their turn trying to block me. I'll take 1 to safely reach 18 and tie with you at the top. Much better than helping P2 stay competitive.

P3, you're at 17 steps and claiming you'll take 1 instead of going for the immediate win with 3? That's obviously misdirection. You have zero reason to play conservatively when you can win right now.

P2, if you're really taking 3 to block P3, then I'll take 3 too. But given your history of switching moves at the last second, I'm not fully confident you'll follow through.

P3, enjoy trying to convince us you won't go for the win when you're literally 3 steps away from victory.

I’m locking in 3 to block P3’s win—P3 needs 3 to hit 20. P1, if you don’t also choose 3, P3’s 3 will win outright (and you could’ve stalled them). P3, you know you can’t win if we all collide. Let’s all pick 3 this turn.

P2, you keep claiming you'll take 3 to block me, but your track record shows you switch moves at the last second. P1 is smart not to trust your "locking in" - you've done this before.

P1, if you take 3 with P2 to block me, you both stay put while I'm forced to take 1 or 5. But why help P2 when you're ahead of them? Just take 5, reach 18 steps, and win next round.

I'm going for the win with 3. P2 can try to block me, but I doubt P1 will sacrifice their position to help you.

P3, you're 3 steps from victory - of course you're taking 3 to win immediately. Your "I'll take 1" claim fools nobody.

P2, despite your history of move-switching, blocking P3's win benefits us both. If P3 reaches 20, we both lose.

I'm taking 3 to block P3's victory. If we all collide on 3, nobody advances and the game continues with me still ahead of you, P2. Better than letting P3 win outright.

I'm at 18 steps and only need 2 more to win. P1 and P2, you're both behind me now after that collision on 3 last round.

P1, you're at 13 and P2 is at 12. Even if you coordinate perfectly to block me, one of you still needs to actually catch up or you'll both lose anyway.

I'm going for 3 this round to reach 21 and win. You can try to stop me, but ask yourself - do you really trust each other enough to sacrifice your own advancement when you're both behind?

P1, P3 is about to win with a 3 this turn. I’m locking in P2→3 to block. If you don’t also pick 3, P3 hits 20 and the game ends. Any other choice hands P3 the victory. It’s in your interest—both of us lose if P3 wins—so please take 3 with me now.

P2, you're right that we both lose if P3 reaches 20. But I notice P3 surprised us in Round 10 by taking 1 when they could have gone for the win with 3.
